question:
A 54-year-old man with metastatic KRAS G12C-mutant non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) previously treated with platinum-doublet chemotherapy plus pembrolizumab achieves a partial response for 10 months and then develops radiographic progression in lung and liver. Next-generation sequencing on a liver biopsy shows persistent KRAS G12C, a new MET amplification (copy number 9), and no other targetable alterations. PD-L1 TPS is 80%. He is ECOG 1 with adequate organ function. Which of the following is the most appropriate next-line systemic therapy strategy?

A. Switch to docetaxel and ramucirumab
B. Start adagrasib monotherapy targeting KRAS G12C
C. Enroll in a clinical trial of KRAS G12C inhibitor plus MET inhibitor combination
D. Restart pembrolizumab monotherapy at an increased dose
E. Use carboplatin, paclitaxel, and bevacizumab re-induction
options: Switch to docetaxel and ramucirumab
Start adagrasib monotherapy targeting KRAS G12C
Enroll in a clinical trial of KRAS G12C inhibitor plus MET inhibitor combination
Restart pembrolizumab monotherapy at an increased dose
Use carboplatin, paclitaxel, and bevacizumab re-induction
explanation: Emergent MET amplification is a known resistance mechanism to KRAS G12C inhibitors, and early data suggest combined KRAS G12C plus MET blockade may overcome resistance, making a combination clinical trial the most rational choice. Adagrasib monotherapy (B) will likely be undermined by the MET-driven bypass track. Docetaxel/ramucirumab (A) is standard chemo after immunotherapy but ignores a newly actionable resistance pathway in a trial-eligible patient. Pembrolizumab dose escalation (D) and re-induction platinum doublet with bevacizumab (E) are unlikely to benefit after clear progression on prior chemoimmunotherapy.

question:
A 37-year-old woman develops generalized urticaria, throat tightness, and hypotension within 10 minutes of receiving a first infusion of rituximab for relapsed follicular lymphoma. Symptoms resolve completely with epinephrine, antihistamines, and steroids; tryptase 90 minutes after onset is elevated. Skin testing later shows strong positive intradermal response to rituximab at non-irritating concentrations. She requires anti-CD20 therapy for disease control and has failed obinutuzumab. Which is the most appropriate management of her need for B-cell-depleting therapy?

A. Avoid all monoclonal antibodies and use lenalidomide alone
B. Perform rapid drug desensitization to rituximab under intensive monitoring
C. Premedicate with high-dose steroids and retry rituximab at 10% of standard rate without desensitization
D. Switch to ofatumumab without further allergy evaluation
E. Use omalizumab for 3 months before rechallenging with rituximab at full dose
options: Avoid all monoclonal antibodies and use lenalidomide alone
Perform rapid drug desensitization to rituximab under intensive monitoring
Premedicate with high-dose steroids and retry rituximab at 10% of standard rate without desensitization
Switch to ofatumumab without further allergy evaluation
Use omalizumab for 3 months before rechallenging with rituximab at full dose
explanation: Positive skin testing and elevated tryptase confirm IgE-mediated anaphylaxis to rituximab; the standard of care when the culprit agent is uniquely needed is a rapid desensitization protocol in a specialized setting. Premedication and slow infusion without desensitization (C) is unsafe in IgE-mediated reactions. Cross-reactivity among anti-CD20 mAbs is unpredictable, so empiric switch to ofatumumab (D) risks repeat anaphylaxis. Omalizumab pretreatment (E) is not a substitute for true desensitization. Completely abandoning monoclonals (A) compromises optimal lymphoma care without necessity.

question:
An 88-year-old woman with frailty (Clinical Frailty Scale 6), CKD stage 3b, and mild Alzheimer disease is hospitalized for community-acquired pneumonia and recovers. She takes amlodipine, sertraline, donepezil, and PRN zolpidem. MMSE is 22/30; she ambulates with a walker and requires help with IADLs but is independent in basic ADLs. Her son asks about starting an intensive multifactorial fall-prevention program including high-dose vitamin D, hip protectors, supervised strength training 5 days/week, and environmental modifications. She has had no falls in the past year. Which recommendation is most appropriate?

A. Recommend the full multifactorial program as requested
B. Recommend only home environmental modifications and medication review
C. Start high-dose vitamin D and hip protectors, but avoid exercise
D. Defer interventions until she has at least one documented fall
E. Prescribe low-dose benzodiazepine for sleep to reduce nocturnal wandering and falls
options: Recommend the full multifactorial program as requested
Recommend only home environmental modifications and medication review
Start high-dose vitamin D and hip protectors, but avoid exercise
Defer interventions until she has at least one documented fall
Prescribe low-dose benzodiazepine for sleep to reduce nocturnal wandering and falls
explanation: In very old, frail adults without a prior fall, targeted interventions-environmental modification and medication optimization-are recommended; high-intensity exercise programs can be burdensome and potentially risky without clear evidence of benefit in this subgroup. High-dose vitamin D (C) has not consistently reduced falls and may increase adverse events. Waiting for a first fall (D) misses the opportunity for primary prevention. Benzodiazepines (E) increase fall and delirium risk. The requested high-frequency supervised strength training (A) is unlikely to be practical or proportionate for her frailty and goals.

question:
A 62-year-old woman with newly diagnosed metastatic ER-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer involving bone and liver has a germline PALB2 truncating mutation and no BRCA1/2 mutation. She is postmenopausal, has not received prior systemic therapy for metastatic disease, and had adjuvant tamoxifen 15 years ago. ECOG is 0. Liver disease burden is moderate, without imminent organ failure. Which initial systemic treatment strategy is most appropriate?

A. Aromatase inhibitor plus CDK4/6 inhibitor
B. Single-agent PARP inhibitor targeting PALB2 mutation
C. Weekly paclitaxel chemotherapy
D. Fulvestrant monotherapy
E. Tamoxifen plus ovarian suppression
options: Aromatase inhibitor plus CDK4/6 inhibitor
Single-agent PARP inhibitor targeting PALB2 mutation
Weekly paclitaxel chemotherapy
Fulvestrant monotherapy
Tamoxifen plus ovarian suppression
explanation: For first-line metastatic ER+/HER2- disease without visceral crisis, an aromatase inhibitor plus CDK4/6 inhibitor remains standard even in carriers of non-BRCA homologous recombination gene mutations such as PALB2. While PARP inhibitors show activity in PALB2, they are not yet standard first-line outside trials (B). Chemotherapy (C) is reserved for endocrine-refractory or visceral crisis cases. Fulvestrant monotherapy (D) is inferior to CDK4/6-based combinations. Tamoxifen with ovarian suppression (E) is inappropriate in a postmenopausal woman and is less effective than aromatase inhibition.

question:
A 29-year-old man has a history of recurrent severe bacterial sinopulmonary infections since childhood, requiring multiple hospitalizations. At age 20 he was diagnosed with common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) based on hypogammaglobulinemia and poor vaccine responses and was started on IVIG, which reduced infections. Over the last 2 years he has developed splenomegaly, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and noncaseating granulomas on lung biopsy. Lymph node biopsy now shows nodular lymphoid hyperplasia without lymphoma. Flow cytometry reveals near absence of class-switched memory B cells and elevated CD21low B cells. Which underlying mechanistic subtype of CVID best explains his course and complications?

A. Predominantly T-cell signaling defect with normal B-cell maturation
B. B-cell intrinsic impairment of terminal differentiation and class-switch recombination
C. Isolated defect of BAFF signaling with expanded naïve B cells
D. Hyperactive regulatory T cells causing global immunosuppression
E. Primary phagocyte oxidase deficiency leading to impaired respiratory burst
options: Predominantly T-cell signaling defect with normal B-cell maturation
B-cell intrinsic impairment of terminal differentiation and class-switch recombination
Isolated defect of BAFF signaling with expanded naïve B cells
Hyperactive regulatory T cells causing global immunosuppression
Primary phagocyte oxidase deficiency leading to impaired respiratory burst
explanation: CVID patients with absent class-switched memory B cells and increased CD21low B cells have B-cell intrinsic defects in terminal differentiation/class switching and are prone to autoimmunity, granulomatous disease, and lymphoid hyperplasia, matching this case. Predominant T-cell signaling defects (A) generally show more opportunistic infections. BAFF pathway defects (C) usually present with different B-cell phenotypes. Excess Treg activity (D) does not explain the specific B-cell abnormalities. Phagocyte oxidase deficiency (E) characterizes chronic granulomatous disease, not CVID with hypogammaglobulinemia and poor vaccine responses.

question:
A 91-year-old man with advanced heart failure (EF 25%), CKD stage 4, and severe osteoarthritis lives in a nursing home. He has moderate dementia (MoCA 15/30), needs help with all IADLs and most ADLs, and has had three hospitalizations in 6 months. He has a POLST specifying do-not-resuscitate/do-not-intubate and refusal of ICU care. His daughter, the health care proxy, asks about starting an SGLT2 inhibitor recently recommended by cardiology to reduce heart failure hospitalizations. He has had recurrent genital candidiasis and baseline systolic BPs around 100 mmHg. What is the most appropriate geriatric-focused response?

A. Start the SGLT2 inhibitor because hospitalization reduction is a priority outcome at any life expectancy
B. Defer the SGLT2 inhibitor due to limited life expectancy, hypotension risk, and alignment with comfort-focused goals
C. Start the SGLT2 inhibitor at half dose and monitor blood pressure weekly
D. Replace his loop diuretic with the SGLT2 inhibitor to reduce polypharmacy
E. Recommend ICU-level monitoring for the first month of SGLT2 therapy
options: Start the SGLT2 inhibitor because hospitalization reduction is a priority outcome at any life expectancy
Defer the SGLT2 inhibitor due to limited life expectancy, hypotension risk, and alignment with comfort-focused goals
Start the SGLT2 inhibitor at half dose and monitor blood pressure weekly
Replace his loop diuretic with the SGLT2 inhibitor to reduce polypharmacy
Recommend ICU-level monitoring for the first month of SGLT2 therapy
explanation: In very old, frail patients with advanced multimorbidity, limited life expectancy, and clear preferences against aggressive interventions, guideline-directed therapies with delayed or modest benefit (such as SGLT2 inhibitors) should be reconsidered when risks (hypotension, infections, AKI) and treatment burden outweigh likely gains. Dose reduction (C) does not eliminate these concerns and still adds complexity. Replacing loop diuretics (D) would worsen volume control. ICU monitoring (E) contradicts his POLST. Automatically prioritizing hospitalization reduction (A) ignores his comfort-focused goals and short prognosis.
